methodology.description: Analyzed closed NegRisk events from Gamma API to estimate pre-resolution YES price sums and identify arb opportunities
methodology.priceEstimation: Used (finalPrice - oneDayPriceChange) to estimate pre-resolution mid prices since historical order books are unavailable

dataCoverage.note: API returns events by closedTime descending; ~850 events/day due to high-frequency crypto and sports markets. 30-day scan would require ~25,000 API calls, impractical.

closestToArb.title: Once Caldas vs. CDP Junior FC
closestToArb.note: Low volume sports market, 1.6% deviation — below 5% threshold

keyFindings: ZERO viable arb opportunities found across 42 NegRisk events in ~1 day of data
Most NegRisk events have YES sums ABOVE 1.0 (median 1.047), meaning the market overprices outcomes — the opposite of an arb opportunity
The 3 events with sums below 1.0 had deviations of only 0.6%, 1.5%, and 1.6% — well below the 5% threshold
Low-deviation events were low-volume sports markets ($6k-$183k), not exploitable at meaningful size
Weather markets and high-volume sports consistently showed sums above 1.0 (vig/overround built in)
limitations: Cannot access historical order book snapshots — only post-resolution prices with 1-day change estimates
1-day price change is an UPPER BOUND on deviation since it includes the resolution move itself
Only ~1 day of data covered due to API pagination limits vs high event volume
Ask prices (what you'd actually pay) are higher than mid prices, making real execution even worse
FOK fill rates unknown — partial fills on illiquid legs would create directional risk
reasoning: The NegRisk arb strategy assumes markets frequently misprice multi-outcome events with YES sums below $0.95. In practice, Polymarket NegRisk markets show the OPPOSITE pattern: the built-in overround/vig means YES sums typically exceed $1.00. Even using generous pre-resolution estimates, zero opportunities exceeded the 5% threshold. The strategy has no edge at current parameter settings and would never execute.
